0: "Do Not Cross" yellow tape marks a property, Tuesday, Oct. 16, 2018, during an ongoing investigation of a couple found dead in their house in Barron, Wis. A Wisconsin teenager who has been missing since... (Associated Press) NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR MADISON, Wis. (AP) â€” A missing Wisconsin girl's parents were shot to death in their house while the girl was home, authorities said Wednesday as they urged the public to keep phoning in tips about her whereabouts. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Investigators have been searching for 13-year-old Jayme Closs since deputies responding to a 911 call early Monday found her parents dead in their home in Barron. The girl, who was ruled out as a suspect on the first day, was gone when deputies arrived. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Barron County Sheriff Chris Fitzgerald said during a news conference Wednesday that autopsies confirmed that James and Denise Closs had been fatally shot and that their deaths have been ruled homicides. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR He said no gun was found at the scene and that evidence from both the house and from the 911 call indicate Jayme Closs was in the family's home when her parents were killed. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Barron is about 80 miles (130 kilometers) northeast of Minneapolis. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Fitzgerald said investigators still have a "100 percent expectation that she's alive," but that even though they've received more than 400 tips, none have been of a credible sighting. He implored the public to share any suspicions, including any behavioral changes in people they know, no matter how small. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "We want to bring Jayme home and put that smile back in her family's hands," said Fitzgerald, who added that investigators don't know whether the attack was random or targeted. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The sheriff called a meeting Wednesday evening with Barron County residents, but he barred reporters from attending, saying he wants to have a private dialogue with the people who elected him. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Bill Lueders, president of the Wisconsin Freedom of Information Council, called the decision to bar the media "offensive." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "The media are uniquely able to help, in terms of getting out information and encouraging people to share tips," Lueders said. "Does he want to find this girl, or does he just want to make a public display of his dislike for the press?"
